name: Hit Point Rolls and what they mean?
author: Jack Bauer

posts.author: Jack Bauer
posts.content:
I have been playing a character, and I have been attempting to maximize my hit point rolls for each level. Is it possible to achieve this by deleveling your character by a couple hundred exp repeatedly until you roll the highest possible amount of hit points? Could someone please explain how it works? I am trying to maximize on how much HP all my characters can get and knowing if I was losing hp on each level would be a big help. Thank you and much love <3

-JB.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Hi Jack (no pun intended!).

Simply put, your max HP per level will be whatever HPs your class attracts at that level. For most fighter-types that will be 10 (though it's 12 for Barbarian and Dwarven Defender), others will be 8 (eg, Cleric), 6 (eg, Rogue), or even 4 for wizardly sorts (can't guarantee that one, never having played an arcanist). In any case, when you level up and choose your class, it will tell you in the description of that class. Then you add your CON modifier (+2, -1, and so on). And finally, anything else that modifies HPs, such as the Toughness feat (+1 HP per level, regardless of class and applied retrospectively, giving an overall +40 HPs) or its Epic variations (a one-off +20 HPs each time it's taken).

I'm sure there will be a way to set the game to give you max HPs each time, but I don't know what it is, so I simply keep re-rolling until I get what I know to be the max for that level/class. It's a little annoying, because I've already done everything else before the HP roll, so have to keep re-inputting whatever feats and skills I want each time, but it generally won't take longer than 2 or 3 minutes before you hit the max.

I must confess that I don't really know what you mean by "deleveling your character by a couple hundred exp", but I hope this helps a bit.

Cheers

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
D&D purists will play with what the dice proffer but there are few PnP environments around these days so if you want to always accrue the maximum HP each level, in the [Server Options] section of your nwnplayer.ini, set the following variable:  Max Hit Points=1.  For PnP, you'd use: Max Hit Points=0 to be subject to the mercy of the dice.

During server play, it's customary to keep quitting the level-up confirmation screen until the HP total reaches the maximum level.

For SP, if you feel your current HP total does not reflect the maximum number (probably because you haven't adjusted the player.ini yet), you can delevel/relevel.   At toon creation (level 1), the values are automatically maxed (or should be) so you'd need to delevel back to level 1 to recapture any missed HP.

The fastest way to accomplish what you are seeking is to use the console command dm_givelevel <x> while in debug mode and then target your PC.  In your case, the number <x> would be a negative number governed by how many levels you decide to relevel (and where <x> would be the positive inverse to the delevel).  Jot down your XP total before using the console because you may need to add a bit of XP back on after the final relevel.   As an example, a level 4 toon would use dm_givelevel -3 then target the PC, followed immediately by dm_givelevel 3  (and target again) to add back the same number of levels.  Use dm_giveXP <x> to make up any difference between the XP at level 4 and what you jotted down.

Naturally, you'd want to make the player.ini change before going through all this tedium.
